name: fedora-iot
description: Task tracker for all things related to the Fedora IoT objective

snapshot.subject: IMA: Integrety Measurement Architecture support in Fedora IoT
snapshot.description: There's numerous components required for full IMA support in Fedora IoT from hardware, early boot and kernel support to userspace tools and custom IMA policies so we'll cover all of those components in this epic break it out from here.

snapshot.subject: Store network credentials in TPM2
snapshot.description: Generally on a device out in the field without DC security we don't want anything to be able to be recovered from a running or non-running system. So we want to be able to store network credentials, whether they be wireless, VPN or some other credential.

snapshot.subject: Support ignition for initial configuration
snapshot.description: Ignition is a tool from CoreOS that supports things like cloud-init provisioning for cloud plus a number of it's own enhancements. The problem is that it's very cloud focused and doesn't support things like encryption of root/data partitions, enrollment of credentials in the TPM2 and probably a number of other requirements of IoT

The firmware is in F-29 updates-testing and there's a scratch kernel here: https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=31934588

snapshot.subject: Finalise Rockchips U-Boot offsets to enable single image with RK devices

snapshot.subject: Sign kernel firmware
snapshot.description:
The enforcing IMA policies require signed firmware for the kernel to load. This should be relatively straight forward based on the same logic as used in the kernel for signing modules.

A bonus would be able to compress firmware in the same manner as kernel modules (but no idea if the kernel firmware handling allows this).

description:
Mozilla IoT Gateway is a nice gateway and web interface for IoT.
https://mozilla-iot.github.io/
Get this in Fedora, and working, as rpms
description_html:
Mozilla IoT Gateway is a nice gateway and web interface for IoT.
https://mozilla-iot.github.io/
Get this in Fedora, and working, as rpms

history.comment:
The final list of rpms needed to have a working gateway  are
* mozilla-iot-gateway
  * Main gateway program
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1673125
* mozilla-iot-gateway-addon-node
  * nodejs hooks for gateway
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1680145
* mozilla-iot-gateway-addon-python
  * python hooks for gateway
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1680143
* nanomsg
  * messaging service used by gateway
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1680140
* nodejs-nanomsg
  * nodejs hooks for nanomsg
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1673126
* python-nnpy
  * python hooks for nanomsg
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1680141

The following package reviews are approved:
mozilla-iot-gateway-addon-python
nanomsg
nodejs-nanomsg
python-nnpy

All of the above packages have been built in rawhide, F30, and F29.
Except nodejs-nanomsg is having problems building on F29.

All packages have passed their reviews.

mozilla-iot-gateway has passed it's review and is working it's way through bodhi.

mozilla-iot-gateway is now in Fedora.

Ya!!!

snapshot.subject: Mozilla IoT Gateway as Fedora container
snapshot.description:
After we have mozilla-iot-gateway in Fedora as rpms, make it into an image.
Include details steps of how to install and use it as a container.
snapshot.description_html:
After we have mozilla-iot-gateway in Fedora as rpms, make it into an image.
Include details steps of how to install and use it as a container.

history.comment:
frankzimmer has made alot of progress on this, and looks like he is close to being done.

https://pagure.io/mozilla-iot-gateway-container

Note: in order for the mozilla-iot-gateway to start-up correctly in the container a new version of the gateway needs to be provided by the mozilla-project or we have to apply the patch https://github.com/mozilla-iot/gateway/pull/1897 downstream.

This patch wasn't merged in time for the gateway 8.1 release.  I think putting it in as a patch for now would allow him to move forward quicker.
I would assign ticket to him, but I currently can't.

The patch was merged in time for gateway 8.1.

Thus, the fixed gateway is currently in Fedora Rawhide, and will make it to F30 and F29 next week.

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2019-cec9355b6c

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2019-a5bc43c0fe

Sadly the patch was not merged in time for 8.1.  I must have somehow grabbed the master branch when I was looking at this.

My apologies, and I am working on fixing this right now.

I have updated the repository with my findings. The gateway starts now using these instructions on my laptop.

I would appreciate some feedback concerning the general approach. I still would like to test it in gnome-boxes

and on actual fedora-iot installation on an RP3b+. 

I have no hardware that allows me to test whether the gateway finds it, but I'm not sure if this is part of the task.

I have run this on Fedora-IoT (f30) on x86_64.   Since you still have to build the image, building it on a RP3b+ will be hard.  Last time I tried to build just a basic image on a RP3b+, the machine ran out of memory.  But I'll still give it a try soon.

The image ran on a IoT image with the following modifications.

*   You cannot create a /mozilla-iot directory. I made and used /mnt/mozilla-iot
*   Most IoT images do not have a browser, and have the firewall turned on.  Thus I had to browse to the gateway remotely, and in order to do that I had to poke firewall holes.

*   firewall-cmd --add-port=4443/tcp --permanent
*   firewall-cmd --add-port=8080/tcp --permanent
*   firewall-cmd --add-port=5353/udp --permanent
*   firewall-cmd --reload

After that, I was able to access the gateway remotely.  Great job.

I think building the image on a RP3b+ does not really work due to the limitation you have mentioned. Building it on a x86_64 and then pulling it down on the RP3b+ is the way to go.

Just for pure curiosity: what is the best license associates with such a project?

I will update the README with you findings and try it myself.
I'm still wondering if we need to port-forward the ports 4443 and 5353 to the outside of the container. I guess we are still missing some functionality if we do not. How could we test this?

Just finished testing on a RPi3B+.  I was able to build the image, both as root and as a user.  It took a while, but it didn't run out of memory.

As root, I was able to run the image just fine.

As a user, I would get the following error.

`ERRO[0381] could not find slirp4netns, the network namespace won't be configured: exec: "slirp4netns": executable file not found in $PATH`

I had to install slirp4netns on the rpi (not the container) for it to run as a regular user.  But after that it ran as a user.  That's a first for me.  I'm thinking maybe podman needs to add that as it's dependency.

But, running as a user, I was able to setup and use a light, so it's passed my tests.

I do think we need to poke 4443 in the container, but not 5353.  5353 needs to be open on the firewall, but since it's udp and not tcp, it seems to be doing ok in the container without any modifications.

To test 5353 is simple.  Does it run and work?  Then 5353 is ok.

To test 4443, you'd have to setup a domain and/or self generate a certificate.  That's a little harder to test, but do-able.

@tdawson I have updated the repository with the comments you made some time ago. The repository is split into two sub-folders: standard and micro-dnf. Please have a look at the moment at the standard sub-folder. If we don't need the micro-dnf approach I can remove the corresponding sub-folder.

Note that the architecture in the Dockerfile is not correct, but I don't know the appropriate abbreviation for the arm architecture.

snapshot.subject: Account lock out policy
snapshot.description:
At the moment Fedora defaults to no account lock out policy which means a remote attacker can just keep trying passwords with no limits.

We need to implement a default policy for Fedora IoT, possibly something as simple as 5 attempts and your out, or possibly something more complex with timeouts etc.

snapshot.subject: treeinfo incomplete with iot composes
snapshot.description:
The IoT treeinfo is incomplete, missing stage2 and images section. 

https://kojipkgs.fedoraproject.org/compose//iot/Fedora-IoT-31-20190809.0/compose/IoT/aarch64/os/.treeinfo

compared to:
https://kojipkgs.fedoraproject.org/compose//branched/Fedora-31-20190816.n.0/compose/Silverblue/aarch64/os/.treeinfo

This causes issues with virt-install not finding the vmlinuz/initrd and needs additional cli options to boot. 

Anaconda also tosses a warning that the stage2 (main image) path is missing but eventually finds it.

snapshot.subject: Support intel tpm2-tss/tools in ima-evm-utils
snapshot.description:
In the ima-evm-utils 1.2 release there was the ability to read TPM 2.0 PCRs added to the tool which in turn added a dep on the IBM tss2 tpm2 stack. We don't really need two TPM2 stacks in IoT so review if we can add support for the ability for the ima-evm-utils to use either stack so we can just depend on one TPM2 stack in IoT (and in Fedora)

https://www.spinics.net/lists/linux-integrity/msg08391.html

snapshot.subject: Compress firmware
snapshot.description:
The kernel now supports loading compressed firmware. We should ship compressed firmware as it will greatly reduce the on-disk size of the firmware package.

Upstream there is a copy-firmware.sh script that creates symlinks for all the firmware where there's a requirement for compatibility, we should extend that to allow a compress option to be passed so all the symlinks are added correctly for compressed firmware.

Also the checksum files at https://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/alt/iot/31/IoT/aarch64/images/ are not signed be any OpenPGP key.

snapshot.subject: Support GPT paritioning
snapshot.description:
It's useful to support GPT partitioning for a number of reasons. Things that need to be taken into account:
* Raspberry Pi's ability to boot firmware from GPT
* Some devices need more space for boot firmware if on the same disk as the OS.

snapshot.subject: Enable countme timer
snapshot.description:
DNF Better Counting support is available in rpm-ostree from  2021.1 and on. The timer unit `rpm-ostree-countme.timer` is not enabled by default. Please enable this so IoT systems are counted.

See https://coreos.github.io/rpm-ostree/countme/

data.comment:
@tdawson I have updated the repository with the comments you made some time ago. The repository is split into two sub-folders: standard and micro-dnf. Please have a look at the moment at the standard sub-folder. If we don't need the micro-dnf approach I can remove the corresponding sub-folder.

Note that the architecture in the Dockerfile is not correct, but I don't know the appropriate abbreviation for the arm architecture.

data.comment:
Just finished testing on a RPi3B+.  I was able to build the image, both as root and as a user.  It took a while, but it didn't run out of memory.

As root, I was able to run the image just fine.

As a user, I would get the following error.

`ERRO[0381] could not find slirp4netns, the network namespace won't be configured: exec: "slirp4netns": executable file not found in $PATH`

I had to install slirp4netns on the rpi (not the container) for it to run as a regular user.  But after that it ran as a user.  That's a first for me.  I'm thinking maybe podman needs to add that as it's dependency.

But, running as a user, I was able to setup and use a light, so it's passed my tests.

I do think we need to poke 4443 in the container, but not 5353.  5353 needs to be open on the firewall, but since it's udp and not tcp, it seems to be doing ok in the container without any modifications.

To test 5353 is simple.  Does it run and work?  Then 5353 is ok.

To test 4443, you'd have to setup a domain and/or self generate a certificate.  That's a little harder to test, but do-able.

data.comment:
I have run this on Fedora-IoT (f30) on x86_64.   Since you still have to build the image, building it on a RP3b+ will be hard.  Last time I tried to build just a basic image on a RP3b+, the machine ran out of memory.  But I'll still give it a try soon.

The image ran on a IoT image with the following modifications.

*   You cannot create a /mozilla-iot directory. I made and used /mnt/mozilla-iot
*   Most IoT images do not have a browser, and have the firewall turned on.  Thus I had to browse to the gateway remotely, and in order to do that I had to poke firewall holes.

*   firewall-cmd --add-port=4443/tcp --permanent
*   firewall-cmd --add-port=8080/tcp --permanent
*   firewall-cmd --add-port=5353/udp --permanent
*   firewall-cmd --reload

After that, I was able to access the gateway remotely.  Great job.

data.comment:
frankzimmer has made alot of progress on this, and looks like he is close to being done.

https://pagure.io/mozilla-iot-gateway-container

Note: in order for the mozilla-iot-gateway to start-up correctly in the container a new version of the gateway needs to be provided by the mozilla-project or we have to apply the patch https://github.com/mozilla-iot/gateway/pull/1897 downstream.

This patch wasn't merged in time for the gateway 8.1 release.  I think putting it in as a patch for now would allow him to move forward quicker.

data.comment:
The final list of rpms needed to have a working gateway  are
* mozilla-iot-gateway
  * Main gateway program
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1673125
* mozilla-iot-gateway-addon-node
  * nodejs hooks for gateway
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1680145
* mozilla-iot-gateway-addon-python
  * python hooks for gateway
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1680143
* nanomsg
  * messaging service used by gateway
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1680140
* nodejs-nanomsg
  * nodejs hooks for nanomsg
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1673126
* python-nnpy
  * python hooks for nanomsg
  * Fedora Package Review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1680141

data.comment:
So with a 4.20.1 kernel and new firmware this should now be testable.

The firmware is in F-29 updates-testing and there's a scratch kernel here: https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=31934588

Finally you need to update /boot/efi/config.txt to have gpu_mem=128

I've had mixed results, with qv4l2 it works, it crashes with Cheese
